Strongly tarry and dark-fruity nose. Fruity flavor with tarred rope, some smoky woodiness, and sourish tannic acids. Medium body, soft CO2. Like Märzen, except smoked ham traded into tar, sweetness reduced, and some complexity added.

Sampled on tap April 2010 @ ChurchKey, Washington DC
This beer arrives from the tap with a huge head (at least for a tap beer), it is two-fingers in height, quite structurally solid looking, leaves lots of lacing as it subsides and is a light tan color.  Big smoke aromatics are noticeable from the get go.  The beer itself is an almost brilliantly clear when held up to the light where it shows a deep red-amber color; as it sits on the table it is a dark plum  color.  Rich smoke aromatics that leans towards almost salty / brine-like in character, while some of the malt character seems to soften the smokiness in the finish.

All the carbonation seems to have been knocked out of this beer during its service from the tap, so it is quite smooth feeling, but it still has some viscous heft to it.  The smoke flavors are more subtle than the aroma would have suggested, but it is still the dominant note (especially in the finish).  Up front there is a nice, sweet maltiness that helps to balance the smoke.  There are almost some berry like flavors to this beer; perhaps from the maillard maltiness that is not really caramel, but definitely rich.  Flavors of umami and peat-smoke (even though this is beechwood smoked malt) are also noticeable here.  This is definitely a beer that has a big smoke character to it, but I am a sucker for beers like this so it definitely hits the spot.

In short: A superior ultra smoky beer with crisp toasted bread and caramel.  Excellent.
How: Tap at In De Wildeman, Amsterdam
The look: Clear bronze body topped by a medium beige head
In long: Nose is very smoky with a smoke signature that is halfway between bacon/ham and wood.  The beer is a little less smoky than the two Schlenkerla classics (Urbock and Marzen).  Taste has crisp caramel, bread crust, smoked bacon, smoked almonds, smoked wood.  The finish is short, dryer and more astringent than other Schlenkerla beers.  An excellent beer although not to the level of their Urbock or even less the Marzen.  Schlenkerla really are the master of smoke.  And yes there can be smoke without fire.  The two best known exceptions are a Shenkerla beer and Willie Nelsons bong.

On draft at De Wildeman. Ruby brown in colour with medium carbonation. Huge beachwood smoke aroma, with a bit of lightly toasted malt backing. The smoke completely dominates in the mouth, along with hints of woodgrain, smoked munich malts, and a touch of yeast. Medium bodied. A real treat for a smokehead like myself.
Opaque thick brown pour with a light tan head.  Mild smoke aroma.  Mild smoked malt flavor with a herbal and floral hop notes and a bitter finish.  Nice mild smoked beer.
Tap @ Bierproeflokaal In De Wildeman. Amber, copper colored brew. Aroma is superb, smells like smoked cheese, I love it. Flavor is smoky, like smoked bacon or ham. Smooth mouthfeel. Great.

Tap at Meibockfestival, Amsterdam. Red-brownish smokey-ale from this Bavarian legend. Not so intense smokey as the rest of their portfolio, so its pretty drinkable for who never drinked this style of beer.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 Very smokey, very bubbly.
Aroma is sweet smoke, taste is sweet but smokey. 
Not as good as the schlenketla märzen.

tap @ OTH
The mother of all smoked beers? Definitely a style worth experimenting.
I believe this is from Brauerei Heller is best enjoyed on tap rather than in bottles.
pours a light brown with thick off-white head.
aroma, smoked malts, some chocolate and caramel nose.
flavors, just incredible smoked malts, light bitter mouthfeel, lingering malty chocolate mouthfeel. Love the way the whole smoke lingers on the palate adding smoke/bacon note that is just at the right amount. Some note of dark fruits can also be noted.
Not sure how else to describe it, its tasty, complex, smoke is intense though not overpowering.
Draft. Smoky and bacony. Dark pour with an oily appearance and mouthfeel. Definitely my favorite smoked beer so far.

On tap at PINT Meibockfestival. Dark brown body with medium head. Nose of smoke, hams and more smoke. Taste is also very smoky, with meats, caramel and charcoal and notes of malt. Finish a bit hoppier.

On tap at PINT Meibockfestival. Clear dark chestnut brown colour, beige head. Aroma of smoke, campfire, smoked bacon, wood. Flavour is smoked eel/bacon, sweet malts, caramel, wood, firm bitter and smoky finish. Just a bit thin at times, but very tasty. Light to medium bodied.

Dark brown colored with medium sized yellow head. Slightly cloudy appearance. Tar, smoke and sweet caramel dominate in aroma, some hops and chocolate also come up. Medium palated. Soft palate. Flavor is more sweet with still dominating tar, smoke and chocolate also here.  aftertaste dries with some hops. Nice and slightly different schlenkerla product.

On tap at Birreria Paradiso. Pours a clear amber with a thin but healthy white head that leaves great lace. Aroma is apple wood smoked bacon. Really insanely rich barbecue and bacon. Taste is greasy bacon, roast pork- really hilarious. Velvety mouthfeel. There are some baked apples, caramel notes, creaminess trying to break through the intense smokiness. Really nice light to medium body. Easy to drink. Very yummy.

Draught at Birreria Paradiso.  Clear multicolored brown with tan head.  Aroma of campfire, bacon and ashtray (but in a good way).  Taste starts sweet and progresses quickly to a burnt caramel.  Tasty.
Not sure how it complies with the reinheitsgebot, however, since the smoke enters the beer, and obviously not all of it leaves.
Draught. Medium high creamy and lasting light brown head. Clear dark brown body. Malty smoky smooth aroma and flavor with low carbonation and a long aftertaste.

(Draft @ Novare Res) Darkish amber with two fingers of solid, creamy light khaki head. Aroma of smoky bacon/meat with some caramel underneath. Nice, smooth, beefy mouthfeel but has sort of a light chalkiness. Flavor is big and smooth and smoky. Smoked meat and woodsmoke. Very light, sweet caramel underneath. Smoke is beautifully integrated. This was excellent but I think Id give a slight edge to the Urbock which is perhaps less sweet (but its been awhile since Ive had it) but both are outstanding. Big lingering smoky aftertaste. This is one of those I thought Id never get to try. Thanks Novare Res for being Schlenkerla devotees!
Clear dark red-orange, tight beige head.  Smoky, meaty aroma.  Taste is rich, almost creamy, bacon, smoked gouda,  bit of a bite on the finish.  The body is what makes this one special.

Huge thanks to spacecoyote for that 22oz counter-pressure-filled bomber. The beer in the glass looks great. Brown-copper colored, very zippy. Wonderful smoky aroma. Starts a bit washy, but shows then wonderful smoky notes, a little bit bacon, but not too much, soft-malty. Finish is also very well balanced with notes of hops and gras, a bit bready, still wonderful smoky without being too intense. Very, very drinkable. A great beer!

10 oz draft. Pours a very deep and lightly hazy burnt red with a small off white head. Aroma is very balanced (I had just drank the Urbock) and this had a much more pronounced dark overripe fruit character, along with the nice mellow smoked wood note. Flavor is even more balanced, the malty fruitiness provides a smooth start before picking up some light earthy spiciness and  of course, a warming and perfectly placed smoked woodiness in a lightly bitter finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Enjoyed the night before easter, really tasty beer.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a medium amber with off-white head and nice lace.  This one has a bright  wood smokiness to the nose.  Not as intense as some of the others, but as always very enticing.  Light and dry.  Very refreshing for such a dramatic flavor.  The hops come out just a little bit more here than they do in some of Schlenkerlas others.  Another great beer from one of the worlds best breweries.

Pours a clear brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is smoke, bacon and some caramel. The flavor is smoke and bacon. The palate is some bitterness and smoke. Overall a good beer with a good balance.

On tap at Church Key DC: Transparent deep mahogany pour with ruby hues and a large, frothy, stringy-lacing off-white head.  Has a huge smoky nose with some peppery notes and doughy malt.  Starts with rich dark toasty caramel malty sweetness and great complex smoky flavor before a smooth slightly more bitter and dry finish.  A very enjoyable and true to style rauchbier.

Medium beige head. Barely translucent hazy dark red body. Smoky bacon aroma with oily notes. Dry-sweetish roasty caramel taste with smoky licorice notes. Mild, rounded mouthfeel. Mid-to-full body. Dry chalky wooden resiny aftertaste with burnt smoky notes. Very nice, and highly drinkable. (0.4l draft at Bishops Arms, Folkungagatan, Stockholm.)

Draft. Hazy dark brown body with large beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, smoke (caramel and meat), caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, smoked meat, caramel, some tobacco/leather, light toffee.  Sticky medium body, faint acidity.
Draught at Ölrepubliken, Göteborg. Amber color, offwhite head. Malty sweetish smoky aroma with vanilla notes. Sweet smoky flavor, ash, bread, licorice notes. Balanced to be a smoked beer.

[March 13, 2010]

Pint at the Bavarian Lodge. Pours a dark brown red with thick lacing and a firm white head. The classic Schlenkerla smoked bouquet is here with defined, clean, mouthwatering bacon, wood smoke, and campfire. I cant get over the remarkable clarity and balance. The flavor is strongly smoky with the same unbeatable smoked quality only Schlenkerla can provide. Perhaps this is less intense than their marzen, but that isnt really saying much. Nonetheless,  the meaty bacon and campfire flavor is still in full effect. The palate is light and clean with a lasting finish of smoke that tries to fade to a mildly sweet malt hint. Excellent.

[March 15, 2010]

Pint glass at the Local Option. How lucky am I to try this beer twice in a week? Im equally as impressed as the first time I had it. The true, complex smoke is all over the place. I find this satisfyingly intense, but this is in comparison to most other weaker smoked beers. Id love to do a side by side with their marzen and see which is the true victor.
(Growler)  Pours an amber-brown body with a moderate creamy off-white head.  Aroma of smoke, sausages, nuts, burning wood, and roasted malt.  Flavor of smoke, roasted malt, bacon, earth, and caramel.
Brown of color with an off white head. An aroma of smoke, sweets, saussages and fire. A flavor of smoke, sweets, caramel and weak bitterness.

Dark ruby color, steady off-white head, lace. Typical Bamberg smokey aroma, malty notes. Medium-bodied, lighter than in eg. Märzen. Smoked ham flavor with semi-crisp carbonation. Slick, smokey aftertaste. Super session smoke beer.

Tap at ølbaren. Dark brown with a hazy look. Poored almost like a slowbeer, so the head was extremly dense and long lasting while the beer turned out a little undercarbonated. Classic Schlenkerla smoke aroma which just doesnt go wrong. Nutty malty flavors with lots of smoke ofcourse. Great!

Well I have a way to go with these smoked beers.  I have a hard time getting past the ham and bacon aromas and flavors to enjoy them.  Maybe with some time I will grow to appreciate them...probably not.  For the style, I can tell it is brewed very well.. hence a pretty good score.

Handbottled. Thanks to KimJohansen and Dedollewaitor. Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, smoke, light salami and light hop. Flavour is caramel, smoke, light hop. Very wellbalanced, and easy to drink.

Its much like the Märzen but different smoked, a bit less smoke and a little thinner. Still a very good brew.

Handbottled @ Ølbaren, Copenhagen. Thanks a lot Kim Johansen. Pours unclear amber with a red hew and a small creamy bubbly head and lacings. Nose is sweet and has a deep maltyness. Lots of caramel and subdued and balanced notes of smoke, bacon and campfire. Smooth and refined. Dammn near a masterpiece and extremely drinkable compared to the rest of the Schlenkerla siblings. Boom!
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2010 On-tap. Ölrepubliken, Göteborg. Red/brown colour with an off-white head. Smoked sausages and a lovely malty caramel background. Smoky, but still very balanced. Very drinkable!

Draft at Bavarian Lodge in Lisle. Pours a very attractive ruby brown with a fluffy head. Nose is nice and rich smoked meats with a pleasant floral aspect, as well as fresh bread. On taste, somewhat subdued smoke notes that balance incredibly well with the noble hops and fresh malts. Its hard to say a smoked beer tastes fresh, but this one does. Outstanding.

Draught at Vihreä Haltiatar, Jyväskylä. Bright dark reddish brown color. The aromas of smoked bacon, toffee, leather and hint of sulfur. The flavor is firmly but pleasantly smoky and woody with smoked bacon with medium to firm bitterness and hint of german hop flavor. Finishes with toffee, tar and bitterness. Smooth and full bodied. Simular to urbock but this one has more hops and can be enjoyed by pints. Very tasty.
Draught @ Gallows Bird. Reddish-coloured with a white head. Bread and smoke in the aroma. Smoky taste has some malts and hint of hops in the background, but more clearly there in the aftertaste.

Draft on tap at Bavarian Lodge (Lisle, IL). Pours a darker copper, a bit hazy, shiny light in bits with a frothy full tannish head that sticks big. Beautiful. Aromas are a nice base smokiness: campfire meats, bacon, a touch of ash, fire pit, fresh crackling wood on the bonfire, a decent caramel, toffee, and bready malt base lies beneath. Not overdone, just enough. Initial is a nice sweet maltiness of bread and biscuits moving into bacon, campfire, a sweet wood, not ashy, but a pleasant smoke on the palate. The smoke and sweet malts linger on the palate, full flavor but a lighter bodied lager than is quite quaffable. Reminds me of bacon buns, this is a wonderfully drinkable smoked lager, light yet the unfiltered nature gives it some great flavor. The head laces very well, the beer provides a light bitterness in the finish, balances well, the bitterness growing in a wave, Noble hops of florals and earthy bitterness is noticeablel. A smoke lovers session beer. Very nice.
Draught. Pours clear brown and lively with large, creamy off-white head. Taste is lightly sweet and palate has a full body, lively carbonation. Aromas have smoke, molasses,  chocolate.

500ml draft pour.  Clear rusty amber color with a small fizz.  Aroma is wonderfully smokey, surprisingly round and mellow, some tea, wood, formaldehyde.  Flavor is same, somewhat tea like, super balanced, light residual sugar, hint of salt, lots of beechwood.  Medium bodied, light drinking, fizzy carb.

Pours amber with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is smokey with hints of hops in the background.  Surprised that the taste is not dominated by the smoke as in other smokes I have had.  Nice beer, that may restore my faith in smoked beers.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2011 First ratingDraught at Ölrepubliken, Göteborg Sweden, on March 1, 2010. My first beer of 2010.Been looking for this beer for a while, but since I havent been able to travel to Bamberg during the time its served, havent been able to get it. When I realized they served it in Göteborg I was glad my two alcohol free months were just about over.Very nice dark reddish brown color, clear though I was expecting it to be hazy. Dense lasting good looking cream colored to tan head. Very very nice malty sweet and of course heavily smoked sausage like, almost metallic, soot scent. Taste is a bit weaker than I expected, guess it havent travelled that well. Still very nice though. Taste of malt, metal, soot, smoke, sausage, some phenoles, a very sippable beer. Smooth a bit full mouthfeel. Medium bitterenss. Apart from the smoke, a very well balanced beer. Though I love the high smoke content, so I will not complain about it!Now I feel like next year perhaps Ill plan to visit Bamberg during that time of year when this beer is supposed to be on, really want to try it fresh from the source, I believe that really would taste amazing.9/5/7/4/17=4.2Rerate, second ratingDraught at Ölrepubliken, Göteborg, on May 6, 2011How lucky am I to walk in for a few quick beers and find this!Slight bit hazy brown color, nice creamy lasting big tan head. Nice, smooth, cream, smoke taste, love it! Feels a lot less sausage like than the A.S.R. Märzen, which is also very nice. Medium to smooth cream like mouthfeel. Smooth, wood, smoke, "charkuterier" scent. Malt and smoke aftertaste. Medium high bitterness.Very nice, very drinkable, very balanced and I regret not to see it more often. Again sets my mind to me going to Bamberg at the right time of year to try it where it should be at its best. Get it if you can!8/5/9/4/17=4.3

On tap at Monks.  The smoke flavor on this beer is too overpowering for me.  Has an aroma of smoke and black olive.  Thin to medium head with a dark copper color.  Creamy and sweet with a barbeque flavor to it.

Draught at Ölrepubliken, Göteborg. 
Unclear mahogany colour with rich creamy head. Fresh, grainy nose with elegant smoked sausage, the Bamberg style. Really chewy mouthfeel and full flavour and rich in flavour. Heavy, yet elegant with a salty smokiness, still elegant, far back in the palate all along, and it lingers with a tad bitterness. Clean maltiness. It finishes so rich and lingering that one doesnt really need much of it. This is a true sipper.
Draught at Ølbaren.Amber colour with large white head who stays.Aroma is rich smoked like ham and  wood some caramel flavor and bready aswell medium body and good smoked finish.

Draught @ Rymy-Eetu, Helsinki 24.2. Finally got to try this beer! Pours mahogany / almost brown colour with a large lasting white head. Aroma is fantastic with smoked ham, wood and hint of tar.  Flavour is bit like Märzen, but this one has liquirice, together with smoked malt and maybe little salty at the end. Enjoyable to the max, what a beer!

Ive been searching for this beer for years and actually had a chance to try it last year during Philly Beer Week. It was on tap at the Yards brewery during the Smoke Em If You Got Em festival. I arrived an hour after the event began and it was already gone. Curses! I heard that this was on at Bierkraft in Brooklyn so I drove there today to pick up a couple of growlers. I love this brewery and this is the only beer they brew that I havent had yet. Im very excited to finally get to try it.

Pours a cloudy, dark copper/mahogany color with dark, golden ruby/orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger soapy, light yellowish-beige head that has excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap. Sporadic chunks of soapy lacing are left behind.

Another amazing smelling beer from Schlenkerla. Lots of smokey toasted malt with hints of campfire, earthy oak, barbecue and bacon. Although the rauch/smoke notes dominate the nose, it is not one dimensional at all. There are hints of earthy oak, caramel malt, bready yeast and faint hops. Of these later characteristics, the oak and caramel are most prevalent. Its a nice change of pace to be able to smell something other than butane in this style of beer. Dont get me wrong I love smoke bombs but the nose on this beer is very complex and unlike any other beer of the style that Ive come across before.

Full bodied which is not surprising for a lent beer but I still wasnt expecting the mouthfeel to be so dense. Nice and smokey yet still well balanced by other flavors making it extremely complex and drinkable. Slightly nutty with lots of toasty malt and bready yeast notes contributing to the full body with a surprisingly strong oak presence and some nice crisp hop bitterness. The hop presence was much more prominent that I had expected and it was a very pleasant surprise. Although these other flavors are present, this beer is still dominated by smoked malt. Lots of smokey campfire flavor with hints of bacon, barbecue, charcoal and burnt toast. As in the nose, there are a lot of different elements contributing to the complexity of this beer. In one sip you get smoke, oak, nut, caramel and bitter dry hops all complimenting each other without anything becoming to overpowering, even the smokiness. Incredibly quaffable and absolutely delicious. Highly recommended!

Dark brown color, large beige head; smoked ham aroma with slight hop notes; medium to full body, smooth carbonation; malty and smoky taste with pleasant bitterness. The ultimate pleasure in the category of beers that you can easily drink two liters or more.

Clear deep amber with a medium beige head. Smoked aroma with roasted malt, caramel, ham and bacon. Flavour had roasted malt, plums, caramel, smoke, ham and bacon. Finished smoked and slightly bitter from the hops.

(Draught at Bishops Arms Sofo, Stockholm) Reddish brown colour with lasting, creamy, beige head. Malty, smoky nose with dark fruit, smoked ham and beech wood fire. Malty, smoky taste with notes of dark/dried fruit, a touch of citrus, lots of smoke (smoked ham) and a generous spicy bitterness in the finish. Slightly above medium body, fairly dry. Lots of smoke, lots of malt and lots of taste. All in exceptional balance. lovely beer.

Draught at Bishops Arms Folkungagatan, Stockholm  Pours out in a deep mahogany colour witha rich lasting sticky tan-colored foam. Smokey rounded aroma of tar, smoked wood, salt and mild smoked ham. Medium-bodied with rounded solid flavors of smoke, toasted malts, mild tar, licorice and crackers. Wonderful mouthfeel; really well-rounded yet solid. Medium-bitter finish of toasted malts, mild licorice, smoke, biscuits and and salt. Great Rauchbier!

Draught at Bishops Arms Folkungagatan, Stockholm  Mahogany colour, rich firm head. Sausage-like beechwood smoke dominates the nose. Medium sweet with soft yet solid mouthfeel. The velvetty, yet powerful smoke flavour surrounds me completely, a condensed, seemless full sized flavour. Remining fabulously drinkable with a balancing late bitterness. At least as good as the keg märzen. I can only imagine what its like from wood at Schlenkerla.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2017 Keg (Angleterre, Helsinki) (7:4:8:4:16=3.9)
Golden brown, small keggy head. Huge smokey aroma, smack bang in the Marzen/Urbock mold. Crisp carbonation. Massive but soft and lush smoked malts, again right in the urbock territory, but a little less smooth than that. Howeve, in addition, this has a little ginger hint too Ive never noticed before - great! Not a flaw anywhere. YUM!
Rerate: 500ml bottle - shared by MadMadMadDrunk - thanks! (7:5:7:4:14=3.7)
Lovely, mellow, smokey, a touch stodgy. Lighter than I remember it. Lovely, but lacking the bone-shaking eye-opening experience I first had.

(Draught at Angleterre, Helsinki) Poured dark brown and clear with medium sized head that had brown shading. Aroma contained smoked ham, tar, grilled sausage and malts. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were smoke, tar, malts, liquorice, grilled sausage, hops and bitterness. Aftertaste contained tar and bitterness. Probably the smokiest beer Ive tasted so far. Also, the beer could replace a meal as the name suggests.

Draught at Angleterre 0.5L. Mild ,alty and  smokeyish nose.  Pale slightly brownish head. Dark coppery colour- Smpky fulfilled malty taste. Slight bitterness from start to the end. Nice smokeness and mild hoppiness.

Pours a hazy ruby color with a tan head. Aroma is smoke, charred hard 
wood, tart, some caramel poking through, and fruity. Flavor is 
caramel, some roast, smoke, tart, and a nice long smokey hardwood 
finish.
On tap at Bullfrog brewery, the guest tap.  This smoked lager/helles had a yellow body and some lace lines.  Bit of smoke, light mouthfeel.  Smoked flavour was decent.

Served on draft at Capital Ale House Fredericksburg. Pours a hazy copper color with a small head. Aroma is smoky with chocolate and caramel notes. Taste is a dry smokiness, cherry and other fruits, toasted grain, faint chocolate and a bitter finish. Medium bodied. Nicely balanced throughout.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2014 Rereake.  Tap @ novareres.  Much cleaner than previous offering a few years back.  Much more drinkable.  Rustic earthy wet doge note offered.   Musty campfire and jerky smoke still offered.   Dry.   Lingering dry woodsey cedar wet old wood smoke.   Neat again.  More drinkable, but still prefer marzen.


Original rake @ 3.5:
tap at beer engine.  Pours brown with an offwhite head.  Notes of smoked beef jerky, campfire, more smoke!  flavor is earth, smokey clothes, rotten fruit.  interesting beer.  if youre into smoked, dont pass this up.

On tap, not sure why this is on now, but Ill take it.  Poured a clear deep brown with a thick slightly off white head.  Nice smoke aroma, pungent but not overpowering.  Smoky flavor with some wonderful background sweetness.  very smooth flavor.  Really tastes like a brown sugar glazed smoked ham, and that is awesome.  Creamy mouthfeel and a delicious smokey finish.  Really nice beer.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: On tap. Clear, warm orangey brown with a dense and handsome off-white head leaving laces. Intense, fat and baconish smoke aroma with a whiff of butter. Full-bodied with a solid malt base with some caramel. Lightly bitter finish. 080409

On draft at the brickstore in GA.  Pours a murky light brown with amber highlights and ample off white head that leaves a nice sparkliing lace.  Nose is a near perfect blend of virginia ham, fatty bacon drippings, and toasty croutons.  Flavor is just a small step down with a ham soup, with a slightly sweet astringent note.  Medium chewy body with moderate carbonation is enjoyable.  Another stellar beer from these guys!  But I still think the marzen is the best.

7/07/2008:  Aecht Schlenkerla Fastenbier has a very inviting aroma that is like a campfire.  It has a great smoky quality that is not the typical smoked Beechwood malt.  The smokiness is almost soft since it doesnt really overpower or overwhelm.  The beer itself is a transparent, dull light brown color.  It has a small but dense and long-lasting off-white head that leaves thick lacing on the glass.  The flavor includes a nice fruity maltiness and floral/noble hoppiness with a great layer of campfire smoke sitting on top.  I really like the charred wood character that also has hints of smoky beef jerky.  It is dry with a slight bitterness that lingers.  This beer is medium-bodied and soft and smooth on the palate.  It has a great balance of malt, hops, and smoke.  Overall this beer is both excellent and delicious.  Why dont they bottle this fantastic beer?!
Draught (5.5% ABV) at the Buckeye Beer Engine in Lakewood, Ohio.  Rating #125 for this beer.

Draft @ Ølbaren, Copenhagen. Pours a clear dark amber color with a longlasting off-white head. Has a smoky malty aroma with hints of caramel. Sweetish malty carmel flavor with nice smoke hints. Has a sweetish smooth malty finish with long smoky aftertaste.

Growler, via GodOfThunder.  Pours a slightly hazy dark amber body with a frothy one inch off-white head that left lots of delicate lacing.  The nose is only a beer Schlenkerla could pull off.  Amazing campfire smokiness with a slightly sweet maltiness, just damn near perfect.  Makes me want a side order of bacon with this.  Up front and aggressive meaty smokiness dominates the flavor from front to back.  Theres a good bit of malt, but not caramel or toffee, just a little toasty and a little sweet.  There may be a bit of a hop influence on the finish, but I just cant get my mind off the smoke to appreciate it.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, fairly soft and creamy in texture with perfect soft pinpoint carbonation.  Lingering smoked jerky like finish.  This was great, its been too long since I had a beer from Schlenkerla.

Growler generously shared by theisti. Pours a pretty, bright reddish iced-tea color with a thin wispy white head. The nose is of subtle smoked malt and smoked pork. An exercise in restraint, when compared to most of the smoked brews that Ive sampled, the aroma on this beer is very, very nice. Light-bodied and lightly effervescent with a pleasant mineral quality at the finish. Soft, sweet, smoky malt with a balancing mineral and lightly bitter finish. This is a very nice beer: easily the best light-bodied smoked beer that Ive tried. Thanks a ton for sharing this treat with us, Tim.
On tap @ Map Room. Resin colored, clear w/ a huge, frothy head; subtle smoked aroma w/ some coriander and spices; lighter than their Marzen and more complex; ends smoky, dry, bitter, caramel...wow!

Growler filled at Uber Tavern in Seattle for me and graciously sent by bvc. Growler was filled 9 days ago. Pour is hazed brown, orange golden with a smallish off white head.  Aroma of soft smoky roastiness, smoked ham and behind that very natural toasted maltiness. Smoke enhances everything, so soft, gentle, just a wonderful nose. Taste is the smoke primarily, clean, fresh with nice full freshly baked toasty bread maltiness behind that. Again the smoke taste is very much smoked ham.  The smoke is forefront, but not overwhelming. Also some light fruit sweetness is present to even out the smoke and malt.  As with the nose, nicely integrated and melded.  Very tasty.  Palate is medium, slightly mouth coating, with an interesting slight bitterness to the finish. Super drinkable.  Wow, really great, thanks for all of the effort on this Brandon.

From a growler, with a big thanks to theisti (and bvc) for the chance to try!  Rating #600, Woo-Hoo!  Pours a slightly hazy brownish orange with a decent tan head that lingers and rouses easily.  Aroma is an intense smoke, meat, light caramel, and campfire, this might be the most intense and interesting smoked aroma Ive smelled yet.  Flavor is more meat, smoke, and light caramel, and is very drinkable.  Excellent stuff, especially on a cool evening, and no doubt my highest rated smoked beer to date.  Thanks again Tim!

Draft at Uber. Pours a crystal clear dark maple-y brown. Towering, thick, fluffy tan head that takes forever to settle. Our man on the case behind the bar had knives, spoons, spare pitchers, spare stanges, and plenty of banter at the ready to manage people while he poured stanges of this one. It looks watery and perfectly translucent, but, man, it billows. Great big fat campfire, bacon, and beef jerky nose--all that smoke finds every possible way to show off in the aromatics, as you might expect. Creamy medium body. Smoke hits you right off the attack. Theres some doughy malt under that, and bits of nitrogen, which is rather unfortunate. Plenty of smoke riding shotgun over all, though. Another big smoky delight from Aecht--never get tired of their rauchy goodness.

Draft at Uber.  Pours a clear but deep rich brown color with amber tints a big fluffy off white head.  Man, I could smell the smoke on this one as Ken placed it on the coaster in front of me.  Aroma is slightly sweet with malt and caramel and then just deep inviting smoke.  Not the kind of smoke that makes you want to switch your position around the campfire, but the kind of smoke that you get with fantastic piece of smoked meat or fish.  As I drink this one, it reminds me of a mix between the Märzen and the Helles.  All the smokey goodness of the Märzen but with a lighter body and the refreshing crispness of the Helles; super drinkable.  I had been anticipating this beer and was not let down.

simply amazoing.Poured a brown hue with a tan head aroma was of smoke,dried fruits and a subtle sweetness.  Flavor was very complex with good smoke notes that never seemed to be overpowering. Flavor had a sublte sweetness to it which balanced out the peat qualities.  Finish  was somewhat dry.
Red amber with a big and firm and lasting white head. Aroma of malt and meaty smoke with a hint of hops. Big and malty flavour with some smoke.

On Tap at redlight.  Oh HELL I love this brewery.  Again its like liquid smoked ham.  Not too thick, really nice hazy color.  Tastes smokey, but not nearly as much as I thought it would be.  This was awesome.

Imperial pint at Three Floyds brewpub.   Brown-amber color.  Hardcore smoky aroma brings me back to Bamberg.  All out smoky taste laced with some crisp hops.  Thick on the palate, closest to the Maarzen Id say Schlenkerla-wise, bit a unique creature unto itself.  Oh so easy and pleasurable to drink, what a beer!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2014 Re-Rate 4/7/12:  This is seriously the best rauchbier out there.  That is really all I have to add.  Superb beer.
Special thanks to Redlight for getting this for us.  My favorite rauchbier.  Strong smell like a smoked meat market.  Flavor is malty and smoked, but not super overpowering.  Fantastic balance and drinkability.  Amazing beer.

Tap @ Ølbaren, Cph.
Pours golden dark with a duper, creamy, off-white head. Good looks. Aroma has burnt meat, smoke (pretty gross). Fair mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, sticky, rotten and smoky meat, light fish and light bitterness. Better than most Schlenkerla, but still terrible.

Lager glass served at the Bavarian Lodge Lisle, IL. Poured a cloudy, brown tone, with a foamy, off white head that reduced to a small ring, and left some sticky lacing. The aroma was immediately campfire smoke and sausage, along with some toasty malt. The flavor was a similar profile with the smoke having a little more of a burnt/char nature. The presence of a medium dryness was also evident in the flavor and finish. Medium bodied, with a lively carbonation. Not too familiar with Smoked Beers and Rauchbiers, but this one was interesting and flavorful.

On tap. Deep mahogany colour with a great tan head.Smoky camp fire aroma with hints of malt. The beer is rich with sweet berries. Strong smoked ale, which starts and finishes in a rich tasty, smoked glass of goodness.

Draft - Very creamy lasting beige head, beautiful chestnut body; Light fresh meaty smoked excellent fresh nose; Very fresh bitter excellent body; Long fresh finish, lots of fresh bitterness, very balanced smoky aroma. Fantastic beer and very very drinkable!

Tap at Bar on Buena.  Murky brown with medium creamy tan head.  Aroma is slight smoke with typical baconess but sweeter malt character coming out.  Flavor is slight smoke, not as thick as some of their other beers, well balanced with the caramel malt and nice, very good.  Medium, creamy body.  Very well balanced and fresh, one of their best.

Draught. Good smoky aroma, campfire and salami. Clear amber brown colour. Big stable creamy tan head. The flavour is nice and smoky, more or less like the aroma, but with a good nice maltiness on top. Flavourful and mellow.

Draught at Ølbaren, Cph. Clear deep amber colour with a nice off white creamy head. Very pleasant smoky aroma with toasty malt. Pleasant mouthfeel. The flavour has a good smokiness with deep malts, caramel and a pleasant bitterness. Smoky dry pleasantly bitter finish.
Tap at Deep Ellum. Outstanding smoked.  Strong smokey odor that hit my nose when is was just put on the table.  Smoked wood flavor quickly dissipates in mouth to smooth malts.  Delicious beer.

Tap at Deep Ellum. Aroma of strong wood smoke and lots of semisweet, bready malt. Flavor again has smoke mostly in the wood department, maybe a touch of meat in there, but continues to be very well buoyed by the huge bready malt. Full-bodied, particularly for a smoked. Maybe not too complex, but simply gorgeous.

Draft at Ginger Man. Pours unclear brown with a beige head. The aroma is both sweet and smoky, with burnt wood, burlap, and toasted grain. The flavor is well balanced with and not at all overpowering in its smokiness. Burnt wood, burlap, smoke, toasted grain, and lighter notes of caramel malts with a very light and dry bitterness that peeks through in the end. Outrageously easy to drink.

On tap at Ølbaren. 
Ruby coloured with a medium dense off white head. 
Aroma is mildly smoked, like fresh homemade butcher sausages and smoked bacon. Lovely. 
Flavour is lots of smoke, with week notes of tar and sweet malt. 
It has a long smoky aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 2012-04-03, draught at Ølbaren, Copenhagen, 9-5-8-4-17=43Dark mahogany color, brown, with red shades; creamy head, of which a thin layer is persistent. Pervasive aroma of smoked ham, and sweet caramel; steady, delicate and powerful at the same time. Very good body, its round but not thick; smooth mouthfeel; caramel flavor, some roasted malts, introducing a late dryness; very strong smoke flavor that combines well with a mild residual sweetness; just some more roasted character and roasted nuts in the final.It seems to have lost the disturbing character of roasted malts of the past, and it gets more similar to a midpoint between Märzen and Urbock; but those still remain superior in elegance. Very nice aroma, firewood and smoke, smoked sausages, less pervasive than last time I had it. Dark caramel flavor, the body is medium structured; smooth and creamy texture; the caramel is just a bit too dark for me, and it takes some time before finding the required sweetness; but the smoke presence is lovely as usual, for Aecht Schlenkerla beers. The final is just a bit harsh (the roasted malt, roasted nuts), very bitter (maybe too much), and not sweet enough. Overall, an excellent beer, but I appreciate less roasted ones.

Draught at Ølbaren, København.
Clear orange coloured with a creamy off white head.
Light smoked aroma of hay with notes of grain, hops and caramel.
Light smoked flavour of caramel, hay and hops with notes of grass.
Hoppy and smoked finish.

Draught at ØLbaren - 1,5 liter. Clear red/brown - offwhite head. Nice smokey aroma. Amber malts, caramel, sweetness, sausage, salami, bacon, lovely malty, high smokey, dryness, nice bitterness. Lovely.

Draft. A chestnut amber beer with a huge creamy tan head. The aroma is sweet and very smokey giving it notes of bacon, tar, and wood. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of smoke again giving it notes of bacon, wood, tar, but also caramel notes from the malt, leading to a dry smokey finish with a light bitterness. The flavor overpowers the aroma once you dig into the beer.Wow.

From tap at Ølbaren. Pours dark clear and golden amber with a huge and light tan head. Leathery smoked and roasted breadish malt aroma. Smoked bacon and salami flavoured with a subdued malty note. Dry and smoked solid base flavour with a light sweetness appearing towards the finish. Ends mild meaty and dry. Dry and bitter into the far finish.

On tap (at Rich Os).  Light garnet brown with a fine offwhite tan head, very slightly hazed.  Campfire smoke, creamy with a light peppery hop profile.  Light cherry maybe?  Full creamy mouth while not overcarbonated at all.  Some real substance.  Sweet malty full bodied lager.  Big campfire smoke, fruity with lightly cherry hinted overtones.  Very creamy for a lager!  Light cherry and a tiny bit of astringency in the finish leaves a very very clean flavor.  What a beautiful beer.
Draft at Waterfront Manhattan.  Pours a cloudy brown with medium head.  That classic Schlenkerla smoky  aroma.  Taste is same with malts.  Good.
Amber colored with minimal head.  Aroma is phenolic and sweet.  Tastes like bacon with light caramel curing, and a solid malt undertone.  Fantastic.

Awesome aroma of a campfire, smoke, cherrywood, some brown sugar sweetness.  The color is a beautiful ruby red, white head, medium carbonation.  the flavor is full of smoke as well, with a small amount of malty sweetness, caramel, brown sugar, and the tiniest hint of grassiness, such as observed in a pilsener.  The finish starts as smoke, as if you were too closee to a fire, but the segues into a mild but nice hop bitterness.  Excellent beer.  Unique and enjoyable.

Growler from Bierkraft in Schlenkerla glass.  Reddish brown with lasting beige head.  Very smoky woodsmoke and toasted caramel aroma.  Smoky toasted caramel brown sugar with lager grassiness and lingering mild bitterness.  Medium body and medium carbo. Very clean and very smoky, but still the toasted caramel of the malts and the hop bitterness come through beautiful.   Ok, Ive been waiting a couple of years to try this one, and it is awesome.  I thought it would be my first 5, but Im not sure its actually better than the marzen, which has less lingering bitterness.  I will have to decide whether this or the marzen will be my first 5.  Anyhow, I think I need to move to Bamberg.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 (draught, at the Schlenkerla Gaststätte, Bamberg) pours a lightly murky brown-amber colour with a smooth off-white head. aroma of delicately smoked ham, grilled sausage and multi-grain bread, with some light herbal notes. flavour is the same, the emphasis being on the smoke with some notes of burnt charcoal and a wonderfully long, smooth smokey and bitter finish. medium body and carbonation, this is just a pleasure to drink.

Draft.  Aroma:  Lots of earthy smokiness, caramel, and some bready malt.  Appearance:  Reddish-brown in color and hazy with small coppery highlights.  Off-white head was small and fleeting with very little lacing.  Flavor:  Big campfire-like woody smokiness with notes of bread, caramel, and cinnamon.  Some nice hoppiness in the midtaste with a noticeable piney/herbal taste.  Finishes with light bitterness and a lingering smokiness.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  Great beer.  The smoke was front and center, but didn’t overwhelm the other flavors.

Draft, Clear umber color with moderate off white head. Light, but deep smoked bacon with a bit of bread dough in the background. Initial smoke flavor followed by a mild pale malt backdrop. The smoke and hops fight for attention in the middle to finish. An interesting combination of light herbs and smoke that is certainly different, but works for me. Finish is long and lightly salty and smokey. I though this might be a bit past prime, but the hops were still fresh and spicy. I could sit with this, my smoker, some ribs of brisket and be happy for the afternoon.

Tap.  Pours to an oddly hued copper body with a tall mostly lasting creamy white head and decent sheet lacing.  The aroma is smoky salmon and juniper berries.  The flavor is smoked for certain.  It has an odd juniper berry, spruce needles, dry old wood, and strange malt base.  Very, very unique.  Theres some things Im detecting but cant place.  Almost like this is a rauch-Belgian.  Perhaps smoked bubblegum with strange hops.  Dry mouthwatering palate and a silken texture.  STRANGE!

Pours dark brown with mahogany tints with very little head and a little lacing.  Wowzers, this one smells like smoked sausage up front with the roasted malts in the background.  The taste follows the aroma with a huge smoked bacon and sausage flavor but the sweet malt base comes through a little more in the taste and balance the brew very well.  The body is medium with the smoky malt lingering on the palate for ages.  Ive only had a few rauchbiers, but this one is the best by a mile.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2009 Draft.  Pours a dark malted body with a a quickly diminishing tan head.  Aroma is lots of smoke, bbq, bacon, burnt wood.  Flavor is liquid smokiness.  A great solid beer.  Put down 2 pints back to back.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. $10.75/pint, unmarked. Ouch. Anyway...clearish orange-brown body, thin off-white to buff head. Toasty nose with burnt caramel notes and smoked peat. Body of fair complexity, with toast and caramel notes quickly pounded into submission by bold smoked peat. Bitter finish. One of the most quaffable smoked beers Ive sampled. Solid beer, but not mind-blowing.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 On tap at Ashleys - Ann Arbor, MI. Aroma is strong right off the bat. Good complex Maple smoke, burning leaves and pine woods. Complex. Pours an interesting mid-brown, amber with a soft soap of off-white above. Flavor bursts as an immediately interesting complex smoke flavor, with Aspen bark, light ash and Beechwood. Wow! This is a fantastic smoke flavor. Spicy, complex and developing some unique earthy character. Just awesome. I can keep going with the flavors, from burning Balsam to Campfire to wood shop. It morphs and lingers for a long, long time. One of the most nuanced and delicious uses of smoke I can image. The toothy, chewy sugars back it up, but stay real dry and crisp. Clean and light, give the excellent smoke character plenty of opportunity to shine. This is tremendous!
pours cloudy orange, nice lacing of the head.  aroma of smoke & mixed spices.  flavor is spicy underarms.  the finish is the same spiciness.  if you like spicy underarms, this is the beer for you.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2008 F-me.  Hand-bottled.  A bit of a hiss as I sprang the pop-top.  Superb sign.  Poured with a bold, thick head.  Ive been waiting too long to try this.  Rich amber color.  Rocky white head has decided to hang around.  Initial whiff is big with big woodsy aromas.  I can smell the glowing embers of a slightly extinguished fire, bacon crisping in a cast-iron skillet.  My mouth waters for this smoky sensation.  Slightly oily on the palate yet smooth and quenching.  Still tingling with hints of carbonation.  Underpinning of sweetness with passionate snips of bittering hops.  As with too few things in life, this has been well worth the wait.  Many thanks to redlight!

On tap at Three Floyds Brewpub and served in a 1/2 litre Schlenkerla glass.  This beer poured a cloudy mahogany with a two-finger thick head of slowly fading tan foam.  Some nice lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of campfire and smoked breakfast ham.  Not overpowering, but very inticing.  The flavor followed suit with heavy smoke, bacon and ham notes, but not in an overdone fasion.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and super smooth.  A heavily smoked brew that remains highly sessionable.  Top notch!

Draft - These beers are unbelievable.  This has a much more subdued smoke aroma and flavor than the other Schlenkerla beers.  It really draws out more of the malt and sweet charachter in the beer,  Truly excellent.
